text: thank you everyone for coming to our talk my name is Celeste Lynne Paul and I'm here with my colleague Josiah Dykstra and we're here to talk about
some work that we've done at the National Security Agency on stress and hacking so first a little bit about
myself I'm a senior researcher and technical adviser at NSA research my backgrounds in human centered computing
which is focused on computer science psychology and design in my background tends to be more on the psychology and
computer science end of things and the reason why I'm so interested in working in cybersecurity specifically is that we
traditionally focus so much on technology in cyber but not as much on the people and I happen to be a people
person good morning I'm Josiah Dijkstra I am the deputy technical director for
NSA's cybersecurity operations organization my PhD is in computer science and I've spent the bulk of my
career looking at technology and trying to make that much more safe and secure I have a great love for cyber security
science and I like to inject that into all the projects that I do and I learned a couple of years ago that I had been
neglecting this really interesting area which is how humans interact and intersect with technology and I've spent
a lot of recent time delving into that and those kind of subjects so the agenda
for today is this on the screen I'm gonna give you a little bit about the NSA just to set the context for the work
that we did so you can understand where we're coming from I will tell you what we mean when we say tactical cyber
operations and what that phrase means to us and Celeste will come and talk about stress and hacking survey that we
developed in a case study we did at the NSA and I'll come back towards the end to talk about how you can put these
results to work in whatever job or environment that you operate in and we'll have plenty of time for questions
at the end of the presentation so for anybody that may be unfamiliar the
National Security Agency is an intelligence organization and a support element to the US Department of Defense
and NSA has two missions given to us through two authorities the first
mission is foreign signals intelligence this is our mandate to collect and process and disseminate on
information to us decision-makers and military planners and operators our
second Authority is cyber security and NSA used to call this information assurance so cyber security is our other
mission to protect national security systems national security systems is anything that handles classified
information or is critical to the conduct of intelligence operations or
military operations so there are a lot
of threats in cyber the top ones for NSA and for the government today are Russia China Iran and North Korea and all of
these have conducted attacks against the United States in recent years Russia for
example we've seen a lot of influence campaigns over a lot of years that has
really ramped up has become very very aggressive more recently in China
there's been a lot of both public and private reporting that shows what used to be large-scale massive very loud
attacks have pulled back a little bit they're a bit more tailored than they used to be but still a very important
nation for the United States in Iran we've seen a change from disruptive and
sort of loud attacks that are sort of now more in line with their geopolitical
norms and in North Korea it's very clear to us that every military conflict has a
cyber component that goes right along with it and so these are the these are the requirements that NSA gets handed to us
from the National Intelligence Organisation so cyber is something we
don't do alone we have a lot of partners in this in this work and we collaborate them with on collaborate with them on a
nearly daily basis so I said that NSA was a member of the intelligence community and we do cyber work with all
of those other members on a daily basis as well we have a close partnership with
the military the combatant commands especially US Cyber Command because US
Cyber Command is the group charged with doing military operations in cyberspace
we have a lot of foreign partners and I think many people are familiar with our five eyes intelligence Alliance this is
our close partnership with Canada the UK Australia and New Zealand and we do
cyber with all of them among our law enforcement partners would be the FBI and the FBI has domestic responsibility
for cyberattacks and espionage and those kinds of disruptive cyber activities we
have a lot of US government partners one for example is the Department of Energy so the D OE is responsible for domestic
energy sectors and foreign threats targeting that sector and NSA has lots
of partnerships and research collaborations with academia I've done lots of these in my own research career
one I'm still involved in is looking at how humans make risk decisions on when
they're online and the goal there is to help at-risk users be more secure on the
Internet so this partnership comes together at the national cybersecurity threat
Operations Center NC talk this is a 24/7 operation center where NSA works with
our partners to do cyber security mission together last month we started
moving into the integrated cyber center and the picture you see on the screen is actually one of the first photos we've
shown of that space so you can see it's a pretty large environment and lets us
do this job together with our partners to ensure that the nation is secure and
safe so cyber is a broad-brush right and
there's many different kinds of operations NSA does for example computer
network exploitation using our SIGINT authorities we also do a variety of
defensive operations for example our blue team is responsible for working
with DoD network operators and owners to make sure we find the vulnerabilities
and secure them before it's too late authorized hacking here refers to our
red team and our red team emulates adversaries that we know about and again tries to protect DoD
networks by pretending to be those adversaries and fixing the vulnerabilities before anyone else can
take advantage of them and the third one here is our hunt mission and in hunts we
use our intelligence to proactively look for adversaries on our own networks and try and route them out to again secure
DoD systems the common thread across all of those things I just described is that they are
very tactical in nature and so when we say tactical cyber operations this is what I'm referring to this is hands on
keyboard kind of work and in your own lives it would be analogous to capture
the flag or Red Team penetration testing and so an operation is a plan sort of
structured activity with a specific goal in mind so in our presentation that's what we're talking about now performance in this
kind of work is really closely tied to speed and precision and so we need a
very highly trained workforce to do this kind of work but the work is also high risk right risk comes with the mission
and failure mean has very real tangible consequences so those pressures are
strong right and stress can really be harmful on the humans doing this kind of
work and it can lead to things like turnover and retention that I think we would all agree are really important
topics in cyber it takes a lot of time and energy and talent to train and
retain that workforce and so we want to keep them as much as we can okay thank
you Josiah so just a pause here I'm really excited
to be here this year at blackhat because there is a great human factors and community track that is covering stress
in a lot of different ways so before our talk you heard about addiction in information security we're talking about
cognitive stress and actual operations so hacking and then this afternoon you'll hear more about burnout
depression and suicide in the hacking community and then tomorrow you'll hear more about PTSD and what this shows is I
think anyone who's worked in cyber security for any period of time has known that these issues have existed but
we're starting to wreak nice them so that we can focus on the health and safety of our workforce so
let's get right into talking about stress stress is an adverse reaction to
events for incidents in the world everyone experiences it differently and
no two events are necessarily the same there are a couple of different types of
stress or degrees of stress that we were concerned with the first one is acute
stress and this is the normal everyday stress of these events that are either unpredictable or just a little bit out
of your control and this is what triggers your flight or flight recite or flight response so your heart rate goes
up your palms get sweaty but as soon as that stressor goes away you go back to
normal you relax and everything is okay and some people do well under stress
they enjoy the excitement of working in a challenging environment they enjoy the
clarity or focus that the stress the additional adrenaline gives them and in
itself it's not necessarily a bad thing when stress becomes a problem is
whenever it becomes repetitive and you experience it so often that your body
both physically and mentally you don't have enough time to recover in between
these stressful events and so you're kind of operating at this high buzz from event to event without getting a chance
to relax and collect yourself again and if you have underlying conditions health
conditions they can start to be aggravated by this even though the stress might be manageable and
uncomfortable however if you're enduring this stress over a long period of time
what we call chronic stress this can start to have a lot of effects on your
health even if you're a healthy person and what we mean by chronic stress there
are a lot of different ways that this could be characterized this could be anything from growing up in a warzone or
being stuck in an unhappy marriage and not knowing how to get out it could be in a dead-end job or
being in a job that you have to have because you need the money but you don't necessarily enjoy it or you have an
abusive work relationship in something that's really key to chronic stress is
this lack of control or no sense of control over the environment around you
so no matter how much you try to exert your will on the things around you and
things just don't seem to work out so stress exists in a lot of different
areas this is air traffic control which for human factors people this is a
classic domain of study and air traffic control has a different kind of stress
so this is a high demand high attention requires lots of working memory and
visual perception in order to get the job done you may be surprised how much
air traffic control is still manual but there are people up in those towers and they are constantly watching the screens
in order to make sure that airplanes don't run into each other basically and
this is very stressful because they have a vigilance condition so they have to
watch for abnormal events that don't occur very often so this is the cognitive work or a cognitive stress
aspect of the job but then they also have the emotional responsibility the
emotional stress because of the responsibilities of lots of people's lives and safety so another domain is in
emergency responders and this is a little bit different from air traffic control this is not necessarily that
long-term vigilance that air traffic controllers get their stress from but
rather these tend to be episodic in a way that have stressors that have a high
emotional and physical toll on the emergency responders involved and this
is important to note because they often need to make snap judgments with incomplete information and whenever
you're stressed out that does affect decision-making and you don't want that to affect emergency responders whenever
they're doing their jobs getting closer into the technology range we have cyber warfare and there are a
lot of different things that affect cyber warfare from a stress perspective and I'll go into that in detail in a
couple of minutes but something that is unique to this kind of work is the shift
work or the length of shift in addition to working in a complex and unpredictable environment and those
types of things are contributing to stress in a different way than the emergency responders or the air traffic
controllers so what is it about hacking that makes it so stressful some of you
may have your own opinions on this hopefully they match with mine or you've
experienced this yourself and you you can resonate with what it is that we are
working on here so cyber is hard right I
mean we get our new boxes full of analytics and they give us fancy new
tools but somehow the job gets harder and harder every year it's because it's
complex right it is a very unpredictable environment where a lot of things can go
wrong and even if you try to control all of your independent variables you can't
there are just too many things too many moving parts and especially in our mission we are in a high-risk
high-reward environment that just ups the stakes of all of these mistakes that could potentially happen whenever things
don't go right so getting back to stress
stress is actually kind of hard to study in some ways because it's so subjective
in individuals experience it in a lot of different ways there are a lot of things
that contribute to stress and so you can't just study one factor versus another factor you have to look at it as
a system it's also very dependent on the environment and so it makes it hard to
transfer things that you know from one domain like air traffic control into
another domain like cyber warfare and since it's so subjective
we need to use subjective measures in to really capture what's going on that's
not necessarily the only way that you can study stress you can study stress objectively and measure effects on the
body however in our environment that's not necessarily the best method for us
to use we don't want to use a study methodology that might induce stress
when we're trying to study stress there
are three things in particular that we were concerned that stress was affecting with our tactical operators the first
one was fatigue and this is just the physical or mental feeling of tiredness the second one was frustration and this
is anxiety and annoyance over lack of control and if you remember my definition of stress control really
contributed to the episodic and chronic conditions and then the last thing was
cognitive workload which is the amount of mental effort needed to use working memory and I'll break out cognitive
workload a little bit more because that in itself is is a little bit complex so the first factor is fatigue to study
fatigue we used something called the sampaoli fatigue scale it was originally developed by the Air Force Research Lab
to study fatigue and fighter pilots and has since been transitioned and used in
a lot of different domains including information technology and here we're just measuring it on a 20-point scale
and we actually anchor it in a couple of different ways just so that people had a
sense of what the scale was like the next one was the nasa TLX or the nasa
nasa task load index and this was developed by nasa in order to study
cognitive workload in space systems and this could be used both for physical
interfaces such as spacecraft or virtual interfaces such as computer user interfaces and this is where cognitive
work and frustrations start to get a little bit complex because there are a lot of things that contribute to it so
the first factor is mental demand which is just measure how mentally demanding the operation was
there's also a physical demand aspect to it this is more important for physical
systems like spacecraft rather than user interfaces but you know some operations
take longer than others and so that length of time that you're doing things sitting in a chair sitting in front of a
keyboard might have some type of effect the next one is time demand which is basically time pressure how pressured
hurried or rushed did you feel in order to complete tasks and then there's also
a measure of overall performance this is a self-assessment of how well you think you did not necessarily what the outcome
of the actual operation was frustration is part of the model and this is how
insecure discouraged irritated stressed and annoyed you are so it's a little bit recursive of a definition there and then
finally we have effort which is how hard did you work in order to accomplish your level of performance so as I mentioned
before stress is very individual and there are a couple of factors that we were more concerned with just because
they were more volatile to those individual differences one of them was fatigue and we were concerned about
measuring the actual effect of all of the operation on fatigue not necessarily
the overall fatigue level of our operators although we did what to capture that as well and so the way to
work out those numbers as we baseline it where we measured fatigue before the
operation and then again after the operation so we had a sense of how tired operators were coming into the operation
how tired they were at the end of the operation overall but then also the
difference between the two so the Delta how much fatigue actually increased over
the course of the operation the other factor that we were concerned with
normalizing was frustration and this is actually one that we didn't anticipate and it came out of pilot studies
where people were bringing a lot of frustration into the operation itself
and we wanted to separate that out from the frustration of the operation its of
the operation and so we did the same thing that we did with fatigue where we asked people how frustrated they were at
the beginning of the operation how frustrated they were at the end of the operation so this all comes together in
what we developed as the cyber operation stress survey there are some additional questions there just for background or
can contextual questions to capture information about the operation itself
but basically you have a short questionnaire at the very beginning of the operation and very end of the
operation in order to capture this experience so we made that survey very
short on purpose we were working in a mission environment and we didn't want
to affect the mission simply by studying our operators we could have potentially
pulled our operators out of mission ran them through training scenario and measured their stress and that's really
what we do in academia it's also very clinical and what we really wanted was
something with ecological validity so that we could actually speak to operations in Mission so let's get to
the NSA part so we took the cost the cyber operation stress survey and we
used it at four different NSA locations so we use it at headquarters in Washington and three of our Cryptologic
centers this includes Georgia Texas and Hawaii there were 126 operators who
participated in the survey and 361 surveys that we collected so this was
about two and a half surveys per operator give or you know plus or minus
we also collected surveys from both the civilian and military population however
the military participants were assigned to NSA these were not US Cyber Command
operators so it should come as no surprise tactical cyber operations cause stress I
would have been shocked if we didn't find this so let's look at some of these
numbers so fatigue on our 20-point scale at the beginning of the operation started about six points and it ended at
about nine and a half points with an increase of 16% with frustration we
started around the same place around six and a half points ended around nine points for an overall difference in 12%
and these differences are statistically significant so let's look into cognitive

physical demand was somewhere near the bottom we are actually a little surprised that physical demand was as

like to look at these numbers individually because they provide more

for the few that we did find art our raw TL x value is somewhat comparable so I

so let's break out cognitive workload and so what I've done here is I've taken

pressure effort and frustration are all positively correlated meaning that as
